questions.question: Which of the following is a complete sentence?
options: A) Jumped over the lazy dog.
B) The quick brown fox.
C) The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog.
D) Over the lazy dog.
questions.explanation: This is a complete sentence because it has both a subject (The quick brown fox) and a predicate (jumped over the lazy dog). It expresses a complete thought.

questions.question: Identify the fragment:
options: A) The sun rises in the east.
B) Every morning at dawn.
C) Birds chirp loudly.
D) Clouds float in the sky.
questions.explanation: This is a fragment because it lacks both a subject and a verb. It's just a time phrase and doesn't express a complete thought.

questions.question: Which sentence is a run-on?
options: A) I woke up early I made breakfast.
B) I woke up early, and I made breakfast.
C) I woke up early. I made breakfast.
questions.explanation: This is a run-on because it combines two independent clauses without proper punctuation or a connecting word.

questions.question: How can you fix this fragment: "Riding a bicycle"?
options: A) Add a full stop at the end.
B) Add a subject and verb: "John is riding a bicycle."
C) Remove "a bicycle."
D) Change "riding" to "rode."
questions.explanation: Adding a subject (John) and a helping verb (is) turns this fragment into a complete sentence by providing who is performing the action.

questions.question: Identify the complete sentence:
options: A) After the rain stopped.
B) Suddenly, without warning.
C) The rainbow appeared in the sky.
D) Beautiful colour arching.
questions.explanation: This is a complete sentence with a subject (The rainbow) and a predicate (appeared in the sky). It expresses a complete thought.

questions.question: Which is a fragment?
options: A) The cake tastes delicious.
B) She baked it yesterday.
C) With chocolate frosting.
D) Everyone enjoyed a slice of the cake.
questions.explanation: This is a fragment because it's a prepositional phrase without a subject or verb. It doesn't express a complete thought on its own.

questions.question: How can you fix this fragment: "Because the car broke down"?
options: A) Add a full stop at the end.
B) Remove "Because."

C) Add an independent clause:
"Because the car broke down, we were late."
D) Change "broke" to "breaks."
questions.explanation: Adding an independent clause completes the thought, turning the dependent clause into a complete sentence.

questions.question: Which sentence uses correct punctuation to avoid a run-on?
options: A) It was raining heavily we decided to stay indoors.
B) It was raining heavily, so we decided to stay indoors.
questions.explanation: This sentence correctly uses a comma and the coordinating conjunction "so" to join two independent clauses, avoiding a run-on.

questions.question: Identify the complete sentence:
options: A) In the blink.
B) Faster than lightning.
C) The cheetah ran across the savanna.
D) Quickly and gracefully.
questions.explanation: This is a complete sentence with a subject (The cheetah) and a predicate (ran across the savanna). It expresses a complete thought.

questions.question: Which is a fragment?
options: A) Before the opening credits.
B) We arrived just in time.
C) The movie starts at eight.
D) The theatre was packed.
questions.explanation: This is a fragment because it's a prepositional phrase that lacks both a subject and a verb. It doesn't express a complete thought on its own.

questions.question: Identify the run-on sentence:
options: A) The sun set the stars came out.
B) The sun set, and the stars came out.
C) The sun set. The stars came out.
questions.explanation: This is a run-on because it combines two independent clauses without proper punctuation or a connecting word.

questions.question: How can you fix this fragment: "Laughing at the joke"?
options: A) Add a full stop at the end.

B) Add a subject:
"The children were laughing at the joke."
C) Remove "at the joke."
D) Change "laughing" to "laughed."
questions.explanation: Adding a subject (The children) and a helping verb (were) turns this fragment into a complete sentence by providing who is performing the action.

questions.question: Identify the complete sentence:
options: A) Under the old oak tree.
B) Leaves rustling in the wind.
C) The squirrel gathered acorns for winter.
D) With its bushy tail.
questions.explanation: This is a complete sentence with a subject (The squirrel) and a predicate (gathered acorns for winter). It expresses a complete thought.

questions.question: Which is a fragment?
options: A) The baby cried loudly.
B) Mom picked her up.
C) To calm her down.
D) She stopped crying eventually.
questions.explanation: This is a fragment because it's an infinitive phrase that lacks a subject and a main verb. It doesn't express a complete thought on its own.

questions.question: Identify the run-on sentence:
options: A) The alarm rang loudly I jumped out of bed.
B) The alarm rang loudly, and I jumped out of bed.
questions.explanation: This is a run-on because it combines two independent clauses without proper punctuation or a connecting word.

questions.question: How can you fix this fragment: "While eating breakfast"?
options: A) Add a full stop at the end.
B) Add an independent clause: "While eating breakfast, I read the newspaper."
C) Remove "While."
D) Change "eating" to "ate."
questions.explanation: Adding an independent clause completes the thought, turning the dependent clause into a complete sentence.

questions.question: Identify the complete sentence:
options: A) After the long journey.
B) But happy travellers.
C) The hikers reached the mountain summit.
D) Finally, at last.
questions.explanation: This is a complete sentence with a subject (The hikers) and a predicate (reached the mountain summit). It expresses a complete thought.

questions.question: Which is a fragment?
options: A) The chef prepared a delicious meal.
B) We enjoyed every bite.
C) With exotic spices and herbs.
D) The restaurant was crowded.
questions.explanation: This is a fragment because it's a prepositional phrase without a subject or verb. It doesn't express a complete thought on its own.

questions.question: Identify the run-on sentence:
options: A) The phone rang I answered it quickly.
B) The phone rang, so I answered it quickly.
questions.explanation: This is a run-on because it combines two independent clauses without proper punctuation or a connecting word.

questions.question: Identify the complete sentence:
options: A) During heavy rainstorms.
B) Lightning flashing across the sky.
C) Thunder rumbled in the distance.
D) With loud booms and crashes.
questions.explanation: This is a complete sentence with a subject (Thunder) and a predicate (rumbled in the distance). It expresses a complete thought.

questions.question: Identify the fragment:
options: A) The students read quietly.
B) Reading books quietly in the library.
C) The students are reading books in the library.
questions.explanation: This is a fragment as it lacks a subject performing the action. To complete it, you might add "The students are" to make it a full sentence.

questions.question: Which of the following is a run-on?
options: A) She loves to dance she practices every day.
B) She loves to dance, so she practices every day.
C) She practices dance every day.
questions.explanation: This is a run-on because two independent clauses are joined without punctuation. Adding a comma and conjunction, or a period, would make it correct.

questions.question: Choose the sentence that is a fragment:
options: A) Before I go to bed.
B) I brush my teeth every night.
C) I read a book before I sleep.
questions.explanation: This is a fragment because it does not form a complete thought on its own. It needs additional information, such as "I brush my teeth before I go to bed."

questions.question: Which sentence needs to be split to fix the run-on?
options: A) At the park for a picnic.
B) We went to the park and had a picnic.
C) We went to the park we had a picnic there.
questions.explanation: This is a run-on sentence because it has two complete ideas without proper separation. Adding a period or conjunction would fix it, such as: "We went to the park, and we had a picnic there."

questions.question: Identify the complete sentence:
options: A) Running through the yard.
B) They are playing outside.
C) After they ate dinner.
questions.explanation: Option B has a subject ("They") and a verb ("are playing") and forms a complete thought. Options A and C are fragments as they don’t give a full idea on their own.
